PASSING STRANGE!!!--The Gazette has
corrected one of thousand Of has falsehoods. He
acknowledges like his worthy. uncle Duff Green,
(of North Room memory )--s' that there was
+. ror in the statement made by us time since,
6 that the Major General (Cooch) of this State had
g acted in an improper manner at the polls" Now
this is noble n the Gazette, but should he continue
to correct erroneous Statements it will be necessary
for him to enlarge his sheet One hours inspection
of his papers since this time last year would furnish
labor for his prolific penfor week at least. This
Ihe is bound to do'' As truth and Justice only are
and haze been the object Of has aim! Ifthese have
been the object of his aim, the Corporal must be a
very Indifferent marksman he fires very wide Of
the mark indeed


| Why does the Gazette pass the matter over thus
smoothly why not say the whole was base false
hood, instead saying there in the state


neat--why not acknowledge the fact, if he really
penned the base article himself taken from the little
tatle of his associates. Or ifcommunicated by any
person assuming the character of Gentleman, give
his name to the public, that he might be held up as
an object of scorn; base assassin of character
No, this would not answer, it might deter other
worthy correspondents from the same course, and
thus deprive the paper of one its most fruitful sources
of information, for effect shall look on this &C Cor


recion,' as one of the meanest of the mean things


the Gazette has lately been guilty Of unless he gives
the author ofthis base slander on the Major Gene


raj to the public. CASTlGATOR.

Bulletin of the Corps ofthe Caucasus-On the 29th
of july the Naib of Furdabad, nominated to this Of
fee, by General Paske witch, having given notice
that considerable body of Persian cavalry was pre-
pairing to attack him. the General in order TO insure
the defence of the inhabitants fthe country and at
the same time take measures suitable to his posi-
ilon Immediately despatched Major General Prince
Vadbolsky, with the regiment of infantry of Tfs,
two regiments of fCossacks of the Black Sea, and six
pieces of cannon, with orders to arrive at Oardabad
on the 3lst of July to employ the LIST OF August IN
putting every thing in order, and TO return on the 3D.
On the other hand, Ekhsan Khan, Naib of Nakhit-
|chevan, entirely to preserve Ourdabad from every
attempt Of the enemy, offered to assemble there IA
part OF the former battalion of Sarbazans Of Max
hitcheyan, which General Paskewitsch engaged to
furnish with the necessary arms, ordering Prince
Vadbolsky to distribute among them four hundred
muskets taken from the Perslans, and to q We them
piece Of cannon, four and half FOUNDER, taken
at Abbas Abad.


! On the same day, thirty-fve Georgian Wagon
drivers who had deserted, arrived at the headquar-
ters; they were sent to General Paskewltsch, by
Abbas Ally, Sultan Of ladjne, one of the Elders Of
the Sharowls, a circumstance which proves the at
tachment ofthat Sultan TO Russia. With the excep-
ton of the Khusen Regimen Of Grenaders four
pieces of light artillery, and hundred and twen-
Ity Cossacks, forming the garrison Of Abhas Abad


all the troops ofthe principal corps were collected
, on the 4th of August, at Karababa, where the eli


mate is infinitely BETTER may be inferred from the


daily decrease of the number of sick. On the 9Th
August, the detachment of Major General Prince
lVadbolsky arrived from Ourdabad and joined the
principal corps


Further accounts say that despatch from the British


convoy at the Court of Persia to MIR. Straord Canning


transmitted the Of great victory gained by the Rus


san the right bank of the Ataxes. The Augsburg Ga


zec, says that the loss of 10000 menby the persas


1000 by the vlctors, is probably, exaggeation.

Our negotiations with the Porte are drawing to-
wards close, and the next advces from Consanti-
nople will apprse us, either that the Sultan has re-
cedea from his determination to refuse all interte-
renee, OF that the Allied Powers have given the me-
cessary instructions for carrying into effect the trea-
ty ofthe 9Th July.


We think the latter more likely nasmuch as the
period fixed for receiving the reply of the Ottoman
Government had expired, when the last message left
Constantinople, and the answer then given was a
firm and perenptory refusal to accept the proffer-
ed mediation. 1t is hardly to be supposed that the
Ambassadors of England, France and Russia, would
afterwards attempt to reopen the negotiation !;
Though the great object of their Governments
is to bring about amicabe arrangement, should
the Sultan, when he found them preparing to quit
his capitol, make any such overtures HIMSELF they
would of course, declare their readiness receive
them


1.-THE question we are now discussing, related 10
any other European Government than that of Tur-
key, we should say, the die cast for it would
be fairly presumable that adecisoD had been delbe-
rately adopted from which every feeling of national
dignity and honor forbade it to recede. But when
we consider what this Power is--how little it is in
huenced by considerations which operate upon other
States and how utterly incapable it is of successful
lily opposing itself to the united power three Mon
arches with whom it is at issue, we can hardly per-
suade ourselves it would have gone even so far as i
has, if it calculated only upon its own strength ant
resources A few days, however, will enable us tt
Judge accurately Of the actual state this
| ton.

,,ton previous to his leaving home. DR.. Hunt call.

SAML. l.. LEWIS.


Further particulars relative 10 this affair, furnish


MIR. Bowie, upon seeing Gen. Quincy fall, drew
ia n;soI Crane, after shooting Gen. Quincy, drew
third pistol Bowie and himself exchanged shots
simultaneously, but without effect Crane fled. By
ths time Major Wright and the two Banchards
from the Red River, came running down from the
,yood with drawn pistols, when Wright stopped,
took aim at Bowie, fred aud missed him he then
advanced three four PAGES, drew another pistol,
nresented it at Bowie, who observed 10 him that he
was unarned, but that if he was man, to shoot.
Major NJ Whorter, who was near Bowie placed an
arnI into his hand--they both fired Wright one
ar two seconds first, and both with effect. Mr..
Bowie was shot through the breast. Wright then
fed. Bowie drew knife and pursued him, and
when within about ten feet of him, he received a
simultaneous fire from the two Banchards, one OF
the balls took effect in his thgn and cut him down
observing which. Wright wheeled, when he and Al
fred Blanchard drew their sword canes. rushed on
and commenced stabbng Bowie, who was PROSTATE.
Bowie scuiied for some seconds until he gained his
seat he then reached up. caught Wright BY the
coat, drew him down to him and at one stab des-
Matched him Mr. Nj. Wells, who had been attend
ns on Gen. Quincy after he had fallen, observing
Bowe's situation, ran to his relief, fired at Blanch-
ard. but fortunately only wounded Blanchard in the
arm-rh. combat here ended. Crane had three
Essstos. Major Wright and the two Blanchards two
each. The gentlemen from Natchez, and its viein-
Ey, who had accompanied them, and who were on
! THE ground in the ailray, were armed-some with
one. and others with two pistols. There was also
hmaght to the field double barreled gun, and other
farms we're near at hand.-ln all, they numbered
Fifteen twenty pistols and one shot gun-the
! bother party had five pistols.

General Chulch has formed camp on Mount Ger
atnos in order to be able to succUur Cornth should
the enemy show any intention of attacking it. He
has also assembled body Of 5000 men, with which
he intends to land on the shores of Atica and Ne
gropont, preparatory to an occupation Of Thermo-
pylae.


lbrahim is still at Modon. The troops Of the Ser
asker divided into six bodies, but being all de-
ached in different directions, they have been beaten
by the Greek guerlas, who have penetrated as far
as Thebes. The garrison of Athens has been con-
siderably diminished, and it is in such weak state,
that if the Greeks could muster the necessary means,
they might attack it with the happiest success.


In general the affairs Of Greece have changed their
appearance for the better. We expect soon to have
some important news from the side of Thessay,
where General Church is going to join the Chiefs OF
Olympus, who have already occupied Thermopyle.
The troops of the Seraskier will thus be deprived of
the provisions and communications they used to OBJ
tain, and keep up through that defe. Acarnaman.
is almost entirely occupied by the Greeks, and it is
hoped that Mssolonghi will soon fall into their
hands,


We have no later news of Lord Cochrane, nor is
it known whether he steered tor the East with his
prize, or whether he remains in the waters of Patras


The St. Petersburgh Journal to the 9Th Inst. has
come to hand this morning. 1t contains the follow
ing news from Georgia =

Turkish arms, and settling the conditions other fl
ture relationship to Turkey. This note prescribed
Ia period OF Is days, whea the answer Of the Grand
'Seignior would be expected.


I'd. That on the 30th of August, when the allot-
ted period might be looked upon as having expired,
the three ambassadors demanded, through their dro-
gumcn the reply of the Refs Efendi, who gave it
verbally and in decided language referred to the
late Turkish manifesto, declaratory of fixed reso-
luton to reject all interference of foreign powers be-
tween the porte and her rebellious subjects fur
ther, that on the 5lst. repetition of their message
by the Christian ministers produced confirmation
of the Turkish resolve.


Sd. That on the 4th instant the ambassadors of
the allies met and not having received any further
satisfaction from the Porte, came to the determine
ton of requiring their passports, and leaving the
Turkish capitol This last act, however, must be
understood to require confirmation.


Upto this period, then,it appears that the dispute
with Turkey far from being settled and it re-
mains to be seen whether the decided tone assumed,
by the ambassadors would bring from the porte any
redeeming message Of nature to reopen the nego-
cations Some expectation seems to be entertain
ed that Austria and Prussia, who have hitherto been
no parties to the quarrel, and are therefore we'll
adapted for the character of mediators, may, for
the sake of preserving peace in Europe. for the
first time interpose, and prevent by their good offices
the threatened rupture.

The packet ship New-York, Bennett, Master, has
just arrived, (ll o'cock,) having sailed on the I'd
inst. to which date have Liverpool papers, and
from London of the 1st.


The course to be pursued by, or towards the
Turks was still undetermined, though according 70
report, the Christian ambassadors had quilted Con
stantlnOple the next short arrival may determine
this question. Already, however, one positive good
has resulted from the ntervention-the alaying and
roconciling the intestine quarrels of the Greeks, to
whom this inteposition has given fresh spirits, and
what is better, united feelings.
The commissions i'll Spain go ON augmennS.
The failure to pay the quarters interest on the
Mexican Bonds had excited great CONSERVATION
among the bond holders, and caused an immediate
fall Of 5 per cent. in stock The Mexican Envoy
had been exerng himself in the city in vain, to par
| ry this event.


Mr. Gallatin, the American minister and his ia
my, we're to embark for this country in the packet
ship of the 9Th October, the Silvanus jenkins.


Capt. Parry had returned from another unsuccess-
4 full expedition. 1t is rather singular that be and
Captain Franklin reached London about the same
time.


Albert Davy, Esq. has been Gazetted as consul
of the U. S. at Hull, in the place of his father de-
ceased. The appointment was made ad interim,
by Mr.. Gallatin, and acknowledged by the British
government.

ate Greek Deputy in London:
Leghorn, Sept. t0.-l have this moment seen a


letter from the Peloponnesus, dated on the 18th Of
August, which says, that scarcely had the news o
: the treaty between England, France and Russia
! been made known, than the dissensions of all par
ties ceased, and the whole of the Palicar hastened
range themselves under their respective Capitan


to march against the enemy. In the space of few
days two corps were formed. one to proceed in thu


direction of Vosttza, and the other against Patras


General Church was encamped near Corinth, witt


5000 men. The troubles at Napoli have been sue


ceeded by the greatest harmony in all parts o


Greece The enthusiasm which now prevails can
r not be extended The loss Of Karaiskaki is depor
n ed, but that Of the Acropos still more so. Ha,
A. that important fortress held out but few day
i. longer all would have been well. A great myster
i. hangs its fall, which nothing but time can re


move."


We have received, this morning, Frankfort ps

b. tnople, August 81, describes warlike preparation
b. to have been vigorously carried in that capital
ne that date. We suboin extracts -

LATEST FROM ENGLAND.

TURKEY following is translation of the
8hote addressed by the Ambassadors OF France, En-
gland and Russia, to the kes Efendi, the 10th ult.
"1J Ills EaceHency the REFS E6eadi.
''The undersigned are charged by their respective
Governments, to make to his Excellency the Refs
AEaendl, the following declaration.


"During six years, the great Powers of Europe
2haye been engaged in endeavours to induce the Sub
lime Porte to enter into patihcatiun of Greece
blt these endeavours have been constantly unayaiI
8ns. and thus war of extermination has been pro-
|3nged between it and the Greeks, the results Of
(which have been, the one hand, caIamtes. the
plation of which is dreadful to humanity and
bn the other hand. T. intolerabe losses to he
commerce OF all nations, while at the same time, it
&hts been possible to admit that the fate of Greece
#has been at all within the control Of the Ottoman
h power.


I "The European Powers have consequently, re-
#doubed the zeal, and renewed the instances which
#hey before made, to determine the Porte, with the
aid OF their mediation. to put an end to struggle
that It was essential to IFS own interest should no
Il longer be kept up. The European Powers have the
more tattered themselves in the hope Of arriving
II at SO happy conclusion, as the Greeks themselves
have in the interval shown desire to avail them
Il selves Of their mediation but the Sublime Porte
has hitherto refused to listen to counses dictated by
\ sentiments of benevnence aud friendship. In this
state of affairs, the Courts of France, England and
isussia have considered it their duty to define, by
special treaty. the line of conduct they are resolved
to observe, in order to arrive at the object toward:
which the wishes and interests Of all the Christian
Powers tend


'ln execution of one Of the clauses of this treaty
the undersigned have been charged to declare to tht
government OF the Sublime Porte, that they now If
torma manner offer their mediation between i
and the Greeks, to put end to the war, and t,
regulate, by a friendly negotiation, the relations
which are to exist between them in future.


"ihat further, and to the end that the success o
this mediation may be facilitated they propose t
me Government of the Sublime Porte AN arInstic
LOT suspendins all acts ofhostly against the Greeks
10 whom similar proposition is this moment ad
afessed Finally, they expect at the end Of fiftee
days the DiTan will clearly make known its deter
mlnatOn.


The undersigned 1atter themselves that it wi
ne coniormable to the wish of the Allied Courts
pat 1t Is their duty not to conceal from the Refs E
ieh'li, that new refusal, an evasive or nsufhcier
answer, even total silence on the part of his Coy
ernnent, will place the Allied Courts under the II,
ee,sty OF recurring 10 such measures as they sha
luage most etlicacious for putting an end to sta
ol y, Things, which is become incompatible even wit
'he true interests of the Sublime Porte, with the S
eaFity OF commerce in general, and with the pete
tranquility of Europe.


Signed, C. GUILLEMINOT,


s. CANNING,


RlBEAUPIERRE.


August 16. 1927

Dover, DelaUare, October s8th 1897


On Wednesday morning came on the trial Of Sol-
omon Greenly charged with burning the public Jail
of Kent County.


The circumstances they were detailed in the
course OF the testimony were as follows The prs-
was confined in the southeast room of the
cond story, on charge of horse-stealing. On the
night of the Goth Inst, between the hours of and
IL O'Clock, the inmates of the prison we're aroused
from their sumbers by the cry Of fire, which pro-
ceeded from the in which the prisoner
confined. A vivid light was emitted from the pris-
oners room, which, examination, proceeded
from the southeast corner OF the upper floor imme-
dately above the prvy, which was on fire. The
prisoner was standing with his clothes tied up in a
bundle, with his face to the door, begging to be let
out The door was then unlocked, and he was ac-
cused of having set fire to the Jail. He denied it,
and said it was an accident. A few sticks of wood
were then discovered on his hearth with the ends
burnt, and but little fire in the fireplace. The
prisoner made his escape, and was apprehended
and brought back to Dover the evening of the
2lst Inst. There had been Il man named James
Spple confined in the same room with the prisoner,
who on the morning ofthe Goth was discharged un-
der the insolvent debtors act TO this man he fire.
quently observed that he had rather be burnt up
than remain in prison until the Quarter Sessions
and said moreover that he should like to the Jail
in a light blaze


The jury, after having retired for about an hour,
brought in verdict of Guilty.
| James Rogers, Esquire, Attorney General for the
State. William Huntington and Charles Marin, Es-
qures for the prisoner


This morning about half past 10 O'Clock the pris-
oner was conducted into Court He came in with
his head inclined forward his eyes down cast, and
his whole appearance indicating sense of misery
and wretchedness.


The Court asked him if he had any thing to offer
why sentence Of death should not be pronounced
against him. He replied that he was innocent. Ills
honor, Chief Justice Johns, then proceeded to ad-
dress and sentence the criminal, which painful duty
he discharged in his usual solemn, feeling and appro
pirate manner adding that he had had the benefit
of far trial and that his council had urged every
thing which could have been urged in bis favor, but
that the circumstances were too strong to admit up
on the minds ofhe Court single doubt of his guilt,
and concluding with the following sentence:


That you Solomon Greenly be taken hence to the
place from whence you came, and there remain in
the custody of the Sheriff until Tuesday the Goth
of November next and be then taken thence by the
said Sheriff to some convenient place, and there,
between the hours Of II o'clock in the forenoon,
and O'Clock in the afternoon be hung by the neck
until you be dead; and may God have mercy upon
your soul.


J, The Court was sensibly effected, and the criminal
seemed to feel the soemnties OF moment SO aw-
full to himself. The prisoner was then re-eoRyey-
ed to prison.

pin, was admitted to practice as an Attorney and

aware.

Nec Iork-The election takes place there on
Monday next-all eyes are turned that way. The
Heroites fondly predict glorious victory for their
Idol So they did in Maryland, Delaware, and
Jersey but they calculated without their host
they would still, however, lead their friends to be-
ieve that they have the ascendency in the two FORM
er states while the latter, say they is still doubt
full. We are quite satisfied they should gain the
same kind Of victory in N. Y. that they have in the
above states This, as paddy says, will be gaining a
loss.


Charge Of ofyMurder.-We learn that the Grand Ju-
ry found bills against Eduydrd Mahom and CatharanA
N'Carten, for the murder of---M M'Carten the
daughter of the latter. Their trial will come on
next Monday, before the Court of Oyer and Ter
miner, at Newcastle.

FAST THE PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH.
The General Assembly Of the Presbyterian Church
in the United States have set apart the second Thurs
day in November inst. as day of Thanksgiving:
Humiliation and Prayer to be observed in all the
churches under their care.

corrected one of thousand Of has falsehoods. He
acknowledges like his worthy. uncle Duff Green,
(of North Room memory )--s' that there was
+. ror in the statement made by us time since,
6 that the Major General (Cooch) of this State had
g acted in an improper manner at the polls" Now
this is noble n the Gazette, but should he continue
to correct erroneous Statements it will be necessary
for him to enlarge his sheet One hours inspection
of his papers since this time last year would furnish
labor for his prolific penfor week at least. This
Ihe is bound to do'' As truth and Justice only are
and haze been the object Of has aim! Ifthese have
been the object of his aim, the Corporal must be a
very Indifferent marksman he fires very wide Of
the mark indeed


| Why does the Gazette pass the matter over thus
smoothly why not say the whole was base false
hood, instead saying there in the state


neat--why not acknowledge the fact, if he really
penned the base article himself taken from the little
tatle of his associates. Or ifcommunicated by any
person assuming the character of Gentleman, give
his name to the public, that he might be held up as
an object of scorn; base assassin of character
No, this would not answer, it might deter other
worthy correspondents from the same course, and
thus deprive the paper of one its most fruitful sources
of information, for effect shall look on this &C Cor


recion,' as one of the meanest of the mean things


the Gazette has lately been guilty Of unless he gives
the author ofthis base slander on the Major Gene


raj to the public. CASTlGATOR.

full articles.article:
Our negotiations with the Porte are drawing to-
wards close, and the next advces from Consanti-
nople will apprse us, either that the Sultan has re-
cedea from his determination to refuse all interte-
renee, OF that the Allied Powers have given the me-
cessary instructions for carrying into effect the trea-
ty ofthe 9Th July.


We think the latter more likely nasmuch as the
period fixed for receiving the reply of the Ottoman
Government had expired, when the last message left
Constantinople, and the answer then given was a
firm and perenptory refusal to accept the proffer-
ed mediation. 1t is hardly to be supposed that the
Ambassadors of England, France and Russia, would
afterwards attempt to reopen the negotiation !;
Though the great object of their Governments
is to bring about amicabe arrangement, should
the Sultan, when he found them preparing to quit
his capitol, make any such overtures HIMSELF they
would of course, declare their readiness receive
them


1.-THE question we are now discussing, related 10
any other European Government than that of Tur-
key, we should say, the die cast for it would
be fairly presumable that adecisoD had been delbe-
rately adopted from which every feeling of national
dignity and honor forbade it to recede. But when
we consider what this Power is--how little it is in
huenced by considerations which operate upon other
States and how utterly incapable it is of successful
lily opposing itself to the united power three Mon
arches with whom it is at issue, we can hardly per-
suade ourselves it would have gone even so far as i
has, if it calculated only upon its own strength ant
resources A few days, however, will enable us tt
Judge accurately Of the actual state this
| ton.

,be meeting. with the view of communicating Cranes
;mention, but unfortunately Dir. c. not at his
lndpngs, or otherwise this premeditated murder
would have been prevented. Your ob't servant.


SAML. l.. LEWIS.


Further particulars relative 10 this affair, furnish


MIR. Bowie, upon seeing Gen. Quincy fall, drew
ia n;soI Crane, after shooting Gen. Quincy, drew
third pistol Bowie and himself exchanged shots
simultaneously, but without effect Crane fled. By
ths time Major Wright and the two Banchards
from the Red River, came running down from the
,yood with drawn pistols, when Wright stopped,
took aim at Bowie, fred aud missed him he then
advanced three four PAGES, drew another pistol,
nresented it at Bowie, who observed 10 him that he
was unarned, but that if he was man, to shoot.
Major NJ Whorter, who was near Bowie placed an
arnI into his hand--they both fired Wright one
ar two seconds first, and both with effect. Mr..
Bowie was shot through the breast. Wright then
fed. Bowie drew knife and pursued him, and
when within about ten feet of him, he received a
simultaneous fire from the two Banchards, one OF
the balls took effect in his thgn and cut him down
observing which. Wright wheeled, when he and Al
fred Blanchard drew their sword canes. rushed on
and commenced stabbng Bowie, who was PROSTATE.
Bowie scuiied for some seconds until he gained his
seat he then reached up. caught Wright BY the
coat, drew him down to him and at one stab des-
Matched him Mr. Nj. Wells, who had been attend
ns on Gen. Quincy after he had fallen, observing
Bowe's situation, ran to his relief, fired at Blanch-
ard. but fortunately only wounded Blanchard in the
arm-rh. combat here ended. Crane had three
Essstos. Major Wright and the two Blanchards two
each. The gentlemen from Natchez, and its viein-
Ey, who had accompanied them, and who were on
! THE ground in the ailray, were armed-some with
one. and others with two pistols. There was also
hmaght to the field double barreled gun, and other
farms we're near at hand.-ln all, they numbered
Fifteen twenty pistols and one shot gun-the
! bother party had five pistols.

full articles.headline: CORFU, , August Ia.
full articles.article:
General Chulch has formed camp on Mount Ger
atnos in order to be able to succUur Cornth should
the enemy show any intention of attacking it. He
has also assembled body Of 5000 men, with which
he intends to land on the shores of Atica and Ne
gropont, preparatory to an occupation Of Thermo-
pylae.


lbrahim is still at Modon. The troops Of the Ser
asker divided into six bodies, but being all de-
ached in different directions, they have been beaten
by the Greek guerlas, who have penetrated as far
as Thebes. The garrison of Athens has been con-
siderably diminished, and it is in such weak state,
that if the Greeks could muster the necessary means,
they might attack it with the happiest success.


In general the affairs Of Greece have changed their
appearance for the better. We expect soon to have
some important news from the side of Thessay,
where General Church is going to join the Chiefs OF
Olympus, who have already occupied Thermopyle.
The troops of the Seraskier will thus be deprived of
the provisions and communications they used to OBJ
tain, and keep up through that defe. Acarnaman.
is almost entirely occupied by the Greeks, and it is
hoped that Mssolonghi will soon fall into their
hands,


We have no later news of Lord Cochrane, nor is
it known whether he steered tor the East with his
prize, or whether he remains in the waters of Patras


The St. Petersburgh Journal to the 9Th Inst. has
come to hand this morning. 1t contains the follow
ing news from Georgia =

Turkish arms, and settling the conditions other fl
ture relationship to Turkey. This note prescribed
Ia period OF Is days, whea the answer Of the Grand
'Seignior would be expected.


I'd. That on the 30th of August, when the allot-
ted period might be looked upon as having expired,
the three ambassadors demanded, through their dro-
gumcn the reply of the Refs Efendi, who gave it
verbally and in decided language referred to the
late Turkish manifesto, declaratory of fixed reso-
luton to reject all interference of foreign powers be-
tween the porte and her rebellious subjects fur
ther, that on the 5lst. repetition of their message
by the Christian ministers produced confirmation
of the Turkish resolve.


Sd. That on the 4th instant the ambassadors of
the allies met and not having received any further
satisfaction from the Porte, came to the determine
ton of requiring their passports, and leaving the
Turkish capitol This last act, however, must be
understood to require confirmation.


Upto this period, then,it appears that the dispute
with Turkey far from being settled and it re-
mains to be seen whether the decided tone assumed,
by the ambassadors would bring from the porte any
redeeming message Of nature to reopen the nego-
cations Some expectation seems to be entertain
ed that Austria and Prussia, who have hitherto been
no parties to the quarrel, and are therefore we'll
adapted for the character of mediators, may, for
the sake of preserving peace in Europe. for the
first time interpose, and prevent by their good offices
the threatened rupture.

full articles.headline:
From the .NeaU York .4merican, Oct 80.
LATEST FROM ENGLAND.
full articles.article:
The packet ship New-York, Bennett, Master, has
just arrived, (ll o'cock,) having sailed on the I'd
inst. to which date have Liverpool papers, and
from London of the 1st.


The course to be pursued by, or towards the
Turks was still undetermined, though according 70
report, the Christian ambassadors had quilted Con
stantlnOple the next short arrival may determine
this question. Already, however, one positive good
has resulted from the ntervention-the alaying and
roconciling the intestine quarrels of the Greeks, to
whom this inteposition has given fresh spirits, and
what is better, united feelings.
The commissions i'll Spain go ON augmennS.
The failure to pay the quarters interest on the
Mexican Bonds had excited great CONSERVATION
among the bond holders, and caused an immediate
fall Of 5 per cent. in stock The Mexican Envoy
had been exerng himself in the city in vain, to par
| ry this event.


Mr. Gallatin, the American minister and his ia
my, we're to embark for this country in the packet
ship of the 9Th October, the Silvanus jenkins.


Capt. Parry had returned from another unsuccess-
4 full expedition. 1t is rather singular that be and
Captain Franklin reached London about the same
time.


Albert Davy, Esq. has been Gazetted as consul
of the U. S. at Hull, in the place of his father de-
ceased. The appointment was made ad interim,
by Mr.. Gallatin, and acknowledged by the British
government.


uFetC6.-EAttdCt vi d tetleI HUN h' Luilullio,
ate Greek Deputy in London:
Leghorn, Sept. t0.-l have this moment seen a


letter from the Peloponnesus, dated on the 18th Of
August, which says, that scarcely had the news o
: the treaty between England, France and Russia
! been made known, than the dissensions of all par
ties ceased, and the whole of the Palicar hastened
range themselves under their respective Capitan


to march against the enemy. In the space of few
days two corps were formed. one to proceed in thu


direction of Vosttza, and the other against Patras


General Church was encamped near Corinth, witt


5000 men. The troubles at Napoli have been sue


ceeded by the greatest harmony in all parts o


Greece The enthusiasm which now prevails can
r not be extended The loss Of Karaiskaki is depor
n ed, but that Of the Acropos still more so. Ha,
A. that important fortress held out but few day
i. longer all would have been well. A great myster
i. hangs its fall, which nothing but time can re


move."


We have received, this morning, Frankfort ps
e. pers to the 23d inst. A paragraph headd Constar
b. tnople, August 81, describes warlike preparation
b. to have been vigorously carried in that capital
ne that date. We suboin extracts -

full articles.headline:
TOR ErGN.

LATE FROM EUROPE.
full articles.article:
TURKEY following is translation of the
8hote addressed by the Ambassadors OF France, En-
gland and Russia, to the kes Efendi, the 10th ult.
"1J Ills EaceHency the REFS E6eadi.
''The undersigned are charged by their respective
Governments, to make to his Excellency the Refs
AEaendl, the following declaration.


"During six years, the great Powers of Europe
2haye been engaged in endeavours to induce the Sub
lime Porte to enter into patihcatiun of Greece
blt these endeavours have been constantly unayaiI
8ns. and thus war of extermination has been pro-
|3nged between it and the Greeks, the results Of
(which have been, the one hand, caIamtes. the
plation of which is dreadful to humanity and
bn the other hand. T. intolerabe losses to he
commerce OF all nations, while at the same time, it
&hts been possible to admit that the fate of Greece
#has been at all within the control Of the Ottoman
h power.


I "The European Powers have consequently, re-
#doubed the zeal, and renewed the instances which
#hey before made, to determine the Porte, with the
aid OF their mediation. to put an end to struggle
that It was essential to IFS own interest should no
Il longer be kept up. The European Powers have the
more tattered themselves in the hope Of arriving
II at SO happy conclusion, as the Greeks themselves
have in the interval shown desire to avail them
Il selves Of their mediation but the Sublime Porte
has hitherto refused to listen to counses dictated by
\ sentiments of benevnence aud friendship. In this
state of affairs, the Courts of France, England and
isussia have considered it their duty to define, by
special treaty. the line of conduct they are resolved
to observe, in order to arrive at the object toward:
which the wishes and interests Of all the Christian
Powers tend


'ln execution of one Of the clauses of this treaty
the undersigned have been charged to declare to tht
government OF the Sublime Porte, that they now If
torma manner offer their mediation between i
and the Greeks, to put end to the war, and t,
regulate, by a friendly negotiation, the relations
which are to exist between them in future.


"ihat further, and to the end that the success o
this mediation may be facilitated they propose t
me Government of the Sublime Porte AN arInstic
LOT suspendins all acts ofhostly against the Greeks
10 whom similar proposition is this moment ad
afessed Finally, they expect at the end Of fiftee
days the DiTan will clearly make known its deter
mlnatOn.


The undersigned 1atter themselves that it wi
ne coniormable to the wish of the Allied Courts
pat 1t Is their duty not to conceal from the Refs E
ieh'li, that new refusal, an evasive or nsufhcier
answer, even total silence on the part of his Coy
ernnent, will place the Allied Courts under the II,
ee,sty OF recurring 10 such measures as they sha
luage most etlicacious for putting an end to sta
ol y, Things, which is become incompatible even wit
'he true interests of the Sublime Porte, with the S
eaFity OF commerce in general, and with the pete
tranquility of Europe.


Signed, C. GUILLEMINOT,


s. CANNING,


RlBEAUPIERRE.


August 16. 1927

full articles.headline: For the Delaware Journal.
full articles.article:
Dover, DelaUare, October s8th 1897


On Wednesday morning came on the trial Of Sol-
omon Greenly charged with burning the public Jail
of Kent County.


The circumstances they were detailed in the
course OF the testimony were as follows The prs-
was confined in the southeast room of the
cond story, on charge of horse-stealing. On the
night of the Goth Inst, between the hours of and
IL O'Clock, the inmates of the prison we're aroused
from their sumbers by the cry Of fire, which pro-
ceeded from the in which the prisoner
confined. A vivid light was emitted from the pris-
oners room, which, examination, proceeded
from the southeast corner OF the upper floor imme-
dately above the prvy, which was on fire. The
prisoner was standing with his clothes tied up in a
bundle, with his face to the door, begging to be let
out The door was then unlocked, and he was ac-
cused of having set fire to the Jail. He denied it,
and said it was an accident. A few sticks of wood
were then discovered on his hearth with the ends
burnt, and but little fire in the fireplace. The
prisoner made his escape, and was apprehended
and brought back to Dover the evening of the
2lst Inst. There had been Il man named James
Spple confined in the same room with the prisoner,
who on the morning ofthe Goth was discharged un-
der the insolvent debtors act TO this man he fire.
quently observed that he had rather be burnt up
than remain in prison until the Quarter Sessions
and said moreover that he should like to the Jail
in a light blaze


The jury, after having retired for about an hour,
brought in verdict of Guilty.
| James Rogers, Esquire, Attorney General for the
State. William Huntington and Charles Marin, Es-
qures for the prisoner


This morning about half past 10 O'Clock the pris-
oner was conducted into Court He came in with
his head inclined forward his eyes down cast, and
his whole appearance indicating sense of misery
and wretchedness.


The Court asked him if he had any thing to offer
why sentence Of death should not be pronounced
against him. He replied that he was innocent. Ills
honor, Chief Justice Johns, then proceeded to ad-
dress and sentence the criminal, which painful duty
he discharged in his usual solemn, feeling and appro
pirate manner adding that he had had the benefit
of far trial and that his council had urged every
thing which could have been urged in bis favor, but
that the circumstances were too strong to admit up
on the minds ofhe Court single doubt of his guilt,
and concluding with the following sentence:


That you Solomon Greenly be taken hence to the
place from whence you came, and there remain in
the custody of the Sheriff until Tuesday the Goth
of November next and be then taken thence by the
said Sheriff to some convenient place, and there,
between the hours Of II o'clock in the forenoon,
and O'Clock in the afternoon be hung by the neck
until you be dead; and may God have mercy upon
your soul.


J, The Court was sensibly effected, and the criminal
seemed to feel the soemnties OF moment SO aw-
full to himself. The prisoner was then re-eoRyey-
ed to prison.

ney and Counsellor of the Supreme Court Of tho
State of Delaware


On motion fJohn Wales, Esq. Ed,oard ". Gil
pin, was admitted to practice as an Attorney and
Counsellor in the Supreme Court Of the State Del
aware.

A Stated Meeting Of the j" DELAW.aRE .aC.aDE-
MY or NATURAL SCIENCE'' WiU be held at the
1ouur Hall, on Saturday meet, at 3 o'clock; 1ohen
addresses zyH be delivered.


.Nov. 9. Il. A. HENDERSON. Secy

Nec Iork-The election takes place there on
Monday next-all eyes are turned that way. The
Heroites fondly predict glorious victory for their
Idol So they did in Maryland, Delaware, and
Jersey but they calculated without their host
they would still, however, lead their friends to be-
ieve that they have the ascendency in the two FORM
er states while the latter, say they is still doubt
full. We are quite satisfied they should gain the
same kind Of victory in N. Y. that they have in the
above states This, as paddy says, will be gaining a
loss.


Charge Of ofyMurder.-We learn that the Grand Ju-
ry found bills against Eduydrd Mahom and CatharanA
N'Carten, for the murder of---M M'Carten the
daughter of the latter. Their trial will come on
next Monday, before the Court of Oyer and Ter
miner, at Newcastle.

FAST THE PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH.
The General Assembly Of the Presbyterian Church
in the United States have set apart the second Thurs
day in November inst. as day of Thanksgiving:
Humiliation and Prayer to be observed in all the
churches under their care.
